awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer for undergraduate research and teaching in chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Occidental College is acquiring a 400 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer equipped with a automatic sample changer to support Professors Jeffrey Cannon, Michael Hill, Andrew Udit, Raul Navarro, Emmanuelle Despagnet-Ayoub and other colleagues. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as permitting study of biologically relevant species. In general, NMR spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this college and other nearby institutions. 

The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts the exploration of synthetic methods for carbon-carbon bond formation and the studies of electrocatalytic carbon-hydrogen bond oxidation at metal-oxo-coated carbon electrodes. The instrumentation is also used for exploring projects varying from energy storage to polymer synthesis. In addition, it benefits investigations of arene dearomatization reactions for natural product synthesis. The spectrometer is also utilized in studies of sulfated ligands displayed on polyvalent bacteriophage for heparin-like anticoagulant activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This Major Research Instrumentation grant award was used to acquire a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometer for use in research and teaching at Occidental College. Occidental College (Oxy) is a small liberal arts college in Los Angeles. The Chemistry Department at Oxy acquired and used the new NMR spectrometer to advance research projects across the chemical sciences where undergraduate researchers were the primary experimental and intellectual drivers.

The instrument itself is a state-of-the-art Burker Avance Neo 400 MHz spectrometer equipped with a broadband probe and autosampling capabilities. The new instrumentation at Oxy enabled data collection that was both more sensitive and more rapid. Many new types of experiments are also now possible, which expands the capabilities of the research programs of the PIs. Not only did this support ongoing projects at the college, but it has allowed the PIs to innovate and expand their research areas.

Intellectual Merit

The new NMR spectrometer was critical in the advancement of many projects led by the Co-PI's at Occidental College. The supported research led to:

  • New catalytic methods for the synthesis of organic molecules that use visible light as the primary energy source.
  • Target-oriented synthesis of small organic molecules, especially the selective production of biologically active structures.
  • Palladium-catalyzed methods for the construction of novel molecular arrangements.
  • The development of new tools to make enxymatic reactions applicable in broader contexts.
  • The design and discovery of new, more efficient electrolytes for industrial electrical energy storage.
  • New reagents for the conversion of carbon dioxide to usable liquid fuels.

As a result, the instrument purchased for this grant enabled multiple publications and presentations where the discoveries of the supported research were disseminated to the community. This includes two publications in The Journal of Organic Chemistry, the premier discipline-specific journal of the American Chemical Society, two manuscripts that have been submitted, and others in late-stage preparation. Over the course of the grant period, over 10 presentations were made at national conferences on work supported by the instrument.

Broader Impacts

The training of undergraduate students in the application and use of modern instrumentation was central to the goals and outcomes of this award. Undergraduate researchers utilized the machine daily to obtain and analyze experimental data. Furthermore, every student of organic chemistry had the opportunity to prepare, submit, and analyze data from their experiments in their chemistry teaching laboratories. Over 100 undergraduate students gained practical first-hand knowledge with cutting-edge instrumentation as an outcome of this award. As a result, we have noticed greater connection and understanding of our students to the importance of spectroscopic data, and their skills at interpreting their results have increased.

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2023
Modified by: Jeffrey Cannon
